attributes.title: Practice Mindfulness to have better sex
attributes.metaDesc: Do you practice mindfulness during sex? Can being mindful help increase pleasure, connection, and intimacy? The practice of mindfulness involves being open, accepting, and curious about the time at hand. It’s being non-judgmental, being present and aware in the moment. Read this article till the end because I’ll share some mindfulness practices that you can do daily which can help improve your overall mindfulness and your sexual relationships.

body.content:
Do you know that you probably have everything you need to improve your sex life? It’s really simple. It’s all in your brain. 

 

We’re going to talk about how mindfulness can improve your sex life.  

 

And I’m going to show some scientific evidence of how mindfulness has improved sexual dysfunction, particularly in women. 

 

So mindfulness is described as a practice where you basically pay attention to what’s going on.  

 

But the key is you see what’s happening. You accept it as it is in a non-judgmental way. 

 

5 Tenets of Mindfulness

 

The first one is non-reactivity to your inner experience.  

 

Typically, this is described as being able to sit with your thoughts without overthinking it, without having a reaction to what your thoughts are, just allowing them to be there. 

 

The next one is observing, just kind of taking note of what’s around you, of the sounds around you or the sensations that you feel and even your emotions.  

 

Some people will also include describing as part of mindfulness. So being able to describe those things, again without judgment. Non-judgment is key in kind of all these areas. So it’s again, being able to see, feel, think about all these things without being critical of what you’re feeling.  

 

And the most important domain, particularly in regards to sex, is acting with awareness. So that means actually being in the moment, not being an autopilot, not just thinking about what you need to do next, or being distracted by other, not letting you engage in the present feeling.  

 

How does the brain changes with mindfulness?

 

So mindfulness has an abundance of ways it can improve your sex life. And I’m going to cover four major ways. But the key and the most fascinating part about this is that there have been studies that have looked at how the brain changes when engaged in mindfulness.  

 

And what they found are two things. 

 

They’ve seen increased brain volume in parts of the cortical brain called the insula and the anterior cingulate gyrus, which are responsible for things like actually perceiving your feelings in your body called interoceptive awareness.  

 

And it also showed decreased activity in parts of the brain that are responsible for rumination or the default mode. 

 

5 Ways Mindfulness improves sex life

 

So this is super powerful and make sure you stick around till the end because I’ll share some mindfulness practices that you can use on a daily basis to help improve your mindfulness overall that will hopefully also improve your sex life if you’re starting to use those more regularly.  

 

So the first way is it improves attentional control. 

 

A lot of the times when we’re having sex we might be thinking about oh, does my body look okay like this? Am I performing well enough? Is the other person enjoying themselves enough?  

 

And those distractions can cause a lot of distress ultimately or make sex less enjoyable. So the number one thing that you’re going to see when you include mindfulness in your sexual practice is that you will have more attention towards your feelings and perceptions that are ongoing during sex.  

 

And this will also lead to an improved body image. Again, a lot of the times more often in women than men but occurs in all genders is actually a poor body image. And poor body image can really affect your confidence during intercourse and your ability to enjoy intercourse.  

 

So incorporating mindfulness will actually help prevent those distractions that go on in your head during sex and allow you to focus it on the act itself. 

 

In fact, in a study of 1000 undergraduate students they looked at the effect of mindfulness on a number of different aspects of sex and what they saw was that people who were more mindful should have less body insecurities, better self perceived performance and self perceived body and overall better sexual satisfaction.  

 

Number three is improved pleasure. 

 

So this is the key, right? We all want to have more pleasure during sex. So everyone who’s reading you should be really motivated right now to incorporate mindfulness in your day-to-day practice because it will help you improve pleasure.  

 

And this comes from bringing awareness to your body. So during mindfulness, you do things like body scans. You kind of try to perceive how your body feels, every part of your body. And when you’re focused on that and you practice mindfulness, even if you get distracted, your body notes that distraction and then focuses back on its sensation that it’s feeling right there and then. 

 

And using that and really focusing on your physical sensations can certainly increase pleasure during intercourse. 

 

However, if you’re using judgment during the course of your sensations, like, oh, am I aroused enough? Am I ready? Am I about to climax? If you’re spending a lot of time thinking about that, it’s not going to work. 

 

It has to be, again, in the frame of no judgment, you are just feeling the sensations and enjoying wherever you are at that moment.  

 

And number four, mindfulness can improve some of the longstanding negative thoughts you have about sex. 

 

So many people have long held thoughts about sex, whether it’s how they were raised or just thoughts that they’ve developed and held onto.  

 

That can include thinking you’re not really good at sex, or maybe that sex is shameful and your response to sex is wrong, or that maybe you’re not capable of performing well enough. If you bring these thoughts with you to a sexual relationship, whether it’s with yourself or someone else, can lead to a negative experience.  

 

So, in people who use mindfulness, they can overcome these negative thoughts. They learn to perceive these things as just what they are thoughts. They are not facts. They are just thoughts. They can let women who feel like they’re frigid or cold during sex realize that that’s not actually true and help them perceive their own arousal better. 

 

It can help people who feel that sex is shameful or embarrassing overcome those feelings, and ultimately it can help you get over any sort of negative thoughts you might have about yourself in relation to sex.  

 

Lastly, mindfulness can improve communication and relationship quality. 

 

In fact, the study where they provided mindfulness based education to couples and parts partners, they found that these couples had significant increases in emotional intimacy as well as communication.  

 

Overall, mindfulness allows you to be more accepting of your partner in a positive way and also communicate in more positive ways, like using things like reflection rather than criticism when talking to your partner.  

 

It may also allow you to be more open to discuss your sexual preferences and also increase your acceptance of those preferences and allow you to experiment and explore more easily. 

 

You might be thinking, this sounds great, but does it really work?  

 

Mindfulness-based Education

 

Well, you don’t have to take my word for it. There’s a handful of studies that have been done looking at mindfulness based education and how it affects particularly female sexual dysfunction. 

 

In a recent study of 1700 women coming to a clinic for regular checkup, they asked them a series of questionnaires about their mindfulness as well as their sexual function.  

 

And what they found was that those who had higher rates of mindfulness were less likely to have female sexual dysfunction, meaning having any sort of problem associated with sex as well as a better sexual function overall, 

 

In studies where women had sexual dysfunction to start with, when they implemented mindfulness based treatments for patients, they found that they increased women’s desire as well as reduce their distress and even their subjective amount of lubrication that they created was higher in women who underwent mindful based education. 

 

In other studies, they found that mindfulness-based therapies have caused increases in desire and arousal as well as decrease in fear around sex for women. 

 

Usually, what mindfulness based education refers to is a number of techniques that are used to help bring mindfulness.  

 

I’ll review these shortly. But often in these studies, they also did some form of education. They educated on what a normal orgasm is and what common myths are related to sex and actually debunked those myths.  

 

What can you do to increase mindfulness?

 

Well, there’s a few things that people often discuss. 

 

First is awareness of the breath. 

 

So, actually taking time every day to close your eyes, sit down, and actually be aware of your breath. Take deep breaths in and out and focus on that breath, exactly what it feels like, how your body moves, how your chest or abdomen moves when you inhale and exhale.  

 

Another often used technique is a body scan. So actually sitting again, typically they suggest sitting in a chair or on the floor with yourself firmly grounded and your back straight and then kind of closing your eyes and trying to go through your body from head to toe through each part of your body to feel exactly what that part of the body is actively feeling.  

 

In any of these sorts of activities, if you feel like your mind is wandering, that’s completely normal. You just notice it. And then once you notice that, you come back to doing whatever you were doing again without judgment, without saying, oh my God, you messed up, right? It’s okay. Everyone does that. 

 

Lastly, there’s loving and kindness meditations where you sit and you think about someone and kind of think about loving thoughts about them and caring thoughts about them.  

 

Like I wish for them to be happy, I wish for them to feel loved, to be safe or live with ease. Those are all sorts of things that often people use in a mindfulness practice. 

 

Apps for mindfulness

 

But for me, what I’ve done, and I found helpful, is to use different types of apps to help me meditate.  

 

Now, this article is not sponsored by anyone. I used headspace for a long period of time and I loved it. Particularly because you can do meditation with your kids. They have little kid meditations which are really designed to help kids listen and sit with you.  

 

So I often did that with my kids a couple of years ago and now I have a peloton membership, so I just do the meditations on the peloton with my kids. And there’s also a free app called Insight Timer. And so I use these to help me work on a meditation practice and increase my mindfulness.  

 

I find that it makes me a happier person and overall enjoy many aspects of my life and I hope you will too. And as always, take care of yourself. 

 

Thank you.
